description: From New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἀκτίς (aktís, “ray”) + ὀστέον (ostéon, “bone”); surface analysis, actin- +‎ -ost- as in osteo-.

entries.meaning: (ichthyology) A bone at the base of a paired fin (of a fish)
examples: The second well-developed actinost is below the vertebra supporting the subcaudal blood-vessels, but that is not so strong proximally as the first; the ribs are not directed downwards, but backwards, and are entirely separated from each other.
